title: Pharmaceutical recipe symbol and a caduceus
content:
Wherre may I find a font that has a Bodoni style Rx for use on medical prescription forms? I now create my own by placing a diagonal line through a Bodoni cap R, but would like to just use a single character.

Is there a symbol font for medical caduceus available? (What is the plural of caduceus? Is it caduceuses?).
author: zap

comments.content:
<cite>What is the plural of caduceus?</cite>

Caducei

From [decodeunicode](http://web.archive.org/web/20120415125340/http:/www.decodeunicode.org/en/u+2624): Caduceus vs. Aesculapius
The Caduceus looks very similar to the Staff of Aesculapius and the two are frequently confused with each other. The Staff of Aesculapius has no wings and just one snake. For the ‘Rx’: Can you show some samples of this character in use?

Both regular and italic versions:

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20120415125340im_/http:/typophile.com/files/Rx_4996.jpg)

I've see it printed on top of my doctor's prescription form that he prints off from his laptop, but I've never looked at the font: this is from a privately released font in my collection.

Does it have a Unicode point?

(Not that this would make it easier, or can you name some fonts featuring [u+2603](http://web.archive.org/web/20120415125340/http:/www.decodeunicode.org/en/u+2603)?)

Florian, thanks. I never would have guessed "Caducei." But then I failed Latin when I was 14.

Now, if someone can tell me where there might be a font with medical symbols. Back in the 50s and 60s, ATF sold "HANDYPACKS" for about $4.00 that contained medical signs among which were "Recipe symbols," "skull & crossbones," "pestle & mortor," and a few other symbols.
The regular is 211E, while the italic is 211F.

Florian: See [FileFormat.info](http://web.archive.org/web/20120415125340/http:/www.fileformat.info/info/unicode/char/2603/fontsupport.htm). On my system, Arial Unicode MS, Code2000, some of the DevaVu forms, and Unicode Symbols all have it. Some fonts display a “borrowed” glyph, but I haven’t discovered where the original is.  
 Linda: Again according to [FileFormat.info](http://web.archive.org/web/20120415125340/http:/www.fileformat.info/info/unicode/char/211f/index.htm), U+211F is the unrelated “response” symbol (℟); no idea what it’s for.  
—Joel
Joel, great advice – I haven’t known that site. Thank you!

Thanks, Joel -- learn something new every day. ;-)

Given that the font I pulled this from is (a) not publicly released, (b) has a wonderful set of Regular characters, a more-than-adequate set of Italics, but no bolds, and (c) has been personally licenced to me for projects, I'm not surprised that it lacks some of the "social niceties" when it comes to font conventions.

Joel: The "response" symbol is used in church liturgies. The part spoken or sung by the pastor is called the "versicle" and is symbolized by ℣ (U+2123). The response, marked by ℟ (U+211F), is sung or spoken by the congregation. The "response" symbol is one up from what is called the "prescription take" symbol ℞ (U+211E).
